captions.text:
INTRO-----
HI I’M ALEX FARNHAM AND THIS IS ANIMALIST

NEWS!
WHAT’S THE SCARIEST ANIMAL YOU CAN THINK

OF?
A BLACK WIDOW?

A SHARK?
GUESS AGAIN, BECAUSE THE KOMODO DRAGON MIGHT

ACTUALLY BE THE MOST TERRIFYING ANIMAL TO
EVER EXIST.

LET ME GIVE YOU A QUICK RUNDOWN ON THIS OVERSIZED
LIZARD.

FIRST OF ALL, THE KOMODO DRAGON IS THE LARGEST
LIVING LIZARD AND CAN GROW TO BE OVER TEN

FEET LONG.
ALTHOUGH THEY CAN RUN OVER THIRTEEN MILES

PER HOUR, KOMODO DRAGONS MAINLY RELY ON STEALTH
AND PATIENCE.

EVEN AFTER THE KOMODO DRAGON SPOTS IT’S
PREY, IT MAY HAVE TO WAIT A WHILE BECAUSE

IT CAN SPOT MOVING OBJECTS NEARLY ONE THOUSAND
FEET AWAY. (binoculars)

BUT IF YOU THOUGHT THEIR VISION WAS GOOD,
CONSIDER THAT THEY CAN SMELL PREY FROM OVER

TWO AND HALF MILES AWAY USING IT’S SNAKE
LIKE TONGUE.

WHEN THE WAIT IS FINALLY OVER, THE KOMODO
DRAGON SMASHES IT’S PREY INTO THE GROUND

USING IT’S SHARP CLAWS, BUT THE WORST IS
YET TO COME.

THE DRAGON’S TEETH ARE ARGUABLY IT’S MOST
POWERFUL WEAPON.

AFTER SHREDDING THEIR PREY TO PIECES, THE
KOMODO DRAGON WILL RELEASE AND LET THEM PAINFULLY

BLEED TO DEATH.
OH AND KOMODO DRAGONS WON’T CARE IF YOU

SCREAM, BECAUSE THEY CAN’T HEAR HIGH OR
LOW PITCHED NOISES.

PLUS IF YOU MANAGE TO ESCAPE, CHANCES ARE
YOUR VICTORY WILL BE SHORT LIVED. (these are

scary things)
ACCORDING TO THE UNIVERSITY OF MELBOURNE,

THEY HAVE THE MOST COMPLEX VENOM GLANDS OF
ANY REPTILE.

MUSCLES IN THE KOMODO’S JAWS AND THROAT
ALLOW IT TO OPEN IT’S LOWER JAW EXTREMELY

WIDE AND SWALLOW HUGE CHUNKS OF MEAT RAPIDLY.
EVEN WEIRDER, KOMODO DRAGONS ARE NOTORIOUS

FOR EATING BONES, HOOVES, HIDE, AND CONSUMING
UP TO EIGHTY PERCENT OF THEIR OWN BODY WEIGHT

IN A SINGLE MEAL.
THESE BEASTS ARE SO TERRIFYING THAT EVEN THEIR

CHILDREN ARE AFRAID OF THEM.
TO KEEP ADULT KOMODOS FROM CANNIBALIZING YOUNG

ONES, THE YOUNG WILL ROLL IN THEIR OWN FECES
TO DETER THEM.

LUCKILY FOR US, KOMODO DRAGONS ONLY LIVE ON
A FEW VOLCANIC INDONESIAN ISLANDS.

WHAT DO YOU THINK IS THE SCARIEST ANIMAL?
LET ME KNOW IN THE COMMENTS DOWN BELOW.

SUBSCRIBE AND CHECK OUT THESE OTHER COOL VIDEOS.
BYE!

comments.author: Steve Jones

comments.text:
+Steve Jones Because you would be surprised how unstudied a species can be 
even when it is heavily studied. It took a medical scanner to find the 
gland in *2009*.   

Walter Auffenberg was the guy who started the bacteria myth in *1981* 
(without any data beyond observation that somehow the animals komodo 
dragons bite died and to his knowledge the creature had no venom). Mind you 
he only threw a hypothesis out there and can't be blamed for the statement 
to be taken as fact without proper testing.

No virulent species of bacteria *that isn't found in any other carnivore's 
mouth* was found when it was actually tested (they actually had less than a 
mammalian carnivore). The bacteria that where deadly could be found in the 
mouth of any other carnivore and the study that had attempted to prove the 
bacteria hypothesis was flawed and got a likely false positive result in 
*2002* (and they only tested dragons for the bacteria at the time).  

Also keep in mind that if the Komodo dragon can get such deadly bacteria 
because of the nature of its teeth and diet wouldn't many monitor lizards 
have the same ability (especially since the komodo dragon has no special 
adaptations to encourage the bacteria that its cousins don't have).
Yet the nature of the discovered venom matches what would be needed for the 
task of hunting large mammals (deer or smaller specifically, native prey 
animals where the wound's comparative size along with the effects of the 
venom work in conjunction quickly) in its own right while those monitor 
lizard that lack the ability of that deadly bite have a much weaker venom 
or none at all depending on the species. Seems rather obvious in hindsight 
that the venom is far more important than any bacteria found in the mouth 
of a meat eating lizard. Bacteria in the environment (mainly the filthy 
water) and the dragon's mouth do help with things like buffalo (who run to 
the filthy water and wallow after being bit on average) but only because 
they would do the same thing to any such wounds from any carnivore 
(especially one who's venom will not let it heal as quickly as it could 
otherwise).
comments.author: Smoking Yagi

thing has been around for much longer. how could something like that go 
unnoticed for so long, on a species that was being studied closely?
comments.author: Steve Jones

comments.text:
That is a myth actually (that was disproven almost the same time it was 
hypothesized but persisted in popular culture). Legitimate venom glands 
where discovered a few years ago (they where small and hard to find). A 
komodo dragon is surprisingly the largest venomous land animal to our 
knowledge at present time.

comments.author: calle bussman

comments.text:
+Timothy Mullins
My point was, they DID mention the venom, but they treated it as the ONLY 
thing that effected prey when it's still unclear how effective the venom is 
or even how the dragons use it. They also didn't mention the bacteria, and 
some of the bacteria are very dangerous. So, they SHOULD have mentioned 
both, yet they didn't: they only mentioned the venom, and while the venom 
has specific highly dangerous proteins, they felt it necessary to think 
that because they even HAVE venom, then the venom is only thing needed to 
kill prey. They treated it as a fact, when it is indeed NOT a fact.
comments.author: 04DarKnight04

comments.text: They touched on it they just said venom
comments.author: Timothy Mullins

comments.text:
It was discovered in 2009 that Komodo dragons do indeed possess glands in 
their lower jaws that appear to secrete venom. However, I haven't seen 
anything that indicates how much venom is secreted in a dragon bite. So, I 
can understand them mentioning the venom, as it most likely is important to 
the success of a dragon bite taking down prey.

However, dragons also, as you mentioned, have up to 57 different strands of 
bacteria in their saliva, some of which are associated with sepsis. And 
while dragons are known to keep their mouths relatively clean (they 
actually try to remove any food debris from their mouths, for example), 
they still have these bacteria growing in their mouths.

I'm not an expert, and I have no intention of spending hours looking for 
studies and info on this matter, but mentioning one of these systems and 
not the other, especially when one system isn't even completely understood, 
shows little actual research and is poor reporting. My best guess is that 
the venom is used to incapacitate or otherwise weaken the immune system of 
prey, while the bacteria use the opportunity to finish them off. However, 
without actual evidence or studies to go off of, this is only conjecture, 
which is why it boggles my mind that they used info from a single study 
(which simply proves the existence of venom and not the potency of amount 
used) as absolute fact, when we actually don't know the exact reason for 
the effectiveness of a Komodo bite.

At the very least, both the bacteria and the venom should be mentioned, but 
it should have been mentioned that it's still unclear how effective each of 
these systems is considering that they work in tandem. it's clearly not the 
bacteria doing all the work, and we don't know exactly how the venom 
contributes, because as I already mentioned, there's nothing indicating the 
amount of venom injected nor is there knowledge of exactly how potent the 
venom is. Therefore, the safest statement would have been to say that both 
are dangerous and both are responsible for the potency of a Komodo's bite.
comments.author: 04DarKnight04
